maml:description.maml:para: Reserves the specified IPv4 address in the scope for a client.

The Add-DhcpServerv4Reservation cmdlet reserves the specified IPv4 address in the scope for a client. Once reserved, the IP address will be leased only to the client identified by the specific client identifier (ID).
Specifies the identifier (ID) of the scope in which the reservation is being created.
Specifies the IPv4 address to be reserved for the client.
Specifies the unique identifier (ID) for the client. For Windows clients, the MAC address is used as the client ID.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the description for the reservation being created.
Specifies the name of the reservation being created. This parameter value can be the host name of the client or a name to be used to identify the reservation on the DHCP server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of client request for which this IP address is reserved. The acceptable values for this parameter are: DHCP, BootP, or Both. The default value is Both.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies the unique identifier (ID) for the client. For Windows clients, the MAC address is used as the client ID.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the description for the reservation being created.
Specifies the IPv4 address to be reserved for the client.
Specifies the name of the reservation being created. This parameter value can be the host name of the client or a name to be used to identify the reservation on the DHCP server service.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the identifier (ID) of the scope in which the reservation is being created.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of client request for which this IP address is reserved. The acceptable values for this parameter are: DHCP, BootP, or Both. The default value is Both.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-DhcpServerv4Reservation -ScopeId 10.10.10.0 -IPAddress 10.10.10.8 -ClientId F0-DE-F1-7A-00-5E -Description "Reservation for Printer"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a reserved IP address for the client identified by the specified client ID.

This example adds all of the reservations in the file named Reservations.csv to the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com. The Import-Csv cmdlet returns the objects with reservation fields and pipes the objects to this cmdlet, which adds these reservations to the DHCP server services. The file named Reservations.csv should contain the reservations in the following comma-separated values (CSV) format:

ScopeId,IPAddress,Name,ClientId,Description 10.10.10.0,10.10.10.10,Computer1,1a-1b-1c-1d-1e-1f,Reserved for Computer1 20.20.20.0,20.20.20.11,Computer2,2a-2b-2c-2d-2e-2f,Reserved for Computer2 30.30.30.0,30.30.30.12,Computer3,3a-3b-3c-3d-3e-3f,Reserved for Computer3

This example converts one of the leases into a reservation. The Get-DhcpServerv4Lease cmdlet returns the IP address lease object and pipes the object to this cmdlet, which creates the reservation with the IP address and client ID in the lease object.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 4
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $freeip = Get-DhcpServerv4FreeIPAddress -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -ScopeId 10.10.10.0 PS C:\> Add-DhcpServerv4Reservation -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -ScopeId 10.10.10.0 -IPAddress $freeip -ClientId F0-DE-F1-7A-00-5E -Description "Reservation for Printer"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a reservation for the client identified by the specified client ID from any of the free IP addresses in the scope 10.10.10.0. The Get-DhcpServerv4FreeIPAddress cmdlet fetches a free IP address in the scope, then this cmdlet reserves an address for the specified client ID.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or more IPv4 reservations for the specified IP addresses or client identifiers (IDs).

The Get-DhcpServerv4Reservation cmdlet gets one or more IPv4 reservations for the specified IP addresses or client identifiers (IDs). If only the ScopeId parameter is specified, then all of the IPv4 reservations from the specified scope are returned.
Specifies the scope ID, in IPv4 address format, from which the reservations are to be retrieved.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the scope ID, in IPv4 address format, from which the reservations are to be retrieved.
Specifies one or more client IDs of the reservations which need to be retrieved. For Windows clients, the MAC address is the client ID.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. dev:remarks.maml:para: This cmdlet gets all of the reservations present in the specified scope on the specified DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com.
This cmdlet gets the reservation present in the specified scope for specified client ID.
This cmdlet gets the reservation information for specified IP address.

This cmdlet gets all the reserved IP addresses from all of the scopes on the server dhcpserver.contoso.com. The Get-DhcpServerv4Scope cmdlet returns all of the scope objects and pipes the objects into this cmdlet, which returns the reservations from all the scopes.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes the IPv4 Reservation from the specified scope.

The Remove-DhcpServerv4Reservation cmdlet deletes the IPv4 reservation from the specified scope. If the ScopeId parameter is specified, then all of the reservations from the scope are deleted. If the IPAddress or ClientId parameter is specified, then one or more specific reservations identified by IP addresses or client identifiers (IDs) are deleted.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies one or more IPv4 addresses for one or more reservations which are to be deleted.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the scope ID, in IPv4 address format, from which the reservations are to be deleted.
Specifies one or more client IDs for one of more reservations which are to be deleted. For Windows clients, the MAC address is used as a client identifier.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example deletes all of the reservations in the specified scope.
This example deletes the specified reservations from the DHCP server service.
This example deletes the specified reservation identified by client ID from the DHCP server service. For Windows computers, the MAC address is used as a client identifier.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 4
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-DhcpServerv4Scope -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com | Remove-DhcpServerv4Reservation -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example deletes all of the reserved IP addresses from all of the scopes on the DHCP server service running on the computer named dhcpserver.contoso.com. The Get-DhcpServerv4Scope cmdlet returns all of the scope objects and pipes the objects into this cmdlet, which deletes the reservations from each of the scopes passed in through the pipeline.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the properties of an IPv4 reservation.
The Set-DhcpServerv4Reservation cmdlet modifies the properties of an IPv4 reservation.
Specifies the IPv4 address of the reservation for which the properties are modified.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the value of the client identifier (ID) to set on the reservation. For Windows clients, the MAC address is used as the client ID.
Specifies the DNS name, or IPv4 or IPv6 address, of the target computer running the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) server service.
Specifies the description to set for the reservation.
Specifies the name to set for the reservation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the type of client that can be leased the reserved IPv4 address. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Dhcp, BootP, or Both.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Specifies the description to set for the reservation.
Specifies the IPv4 address of the reservation for which the properties are modified.
Specifies the name to set for the reservation.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-DhcpServerv4Reservation -ComputerName dhcpserver.contoso.com -IPAddress 10.10.10.5 -Description "Fourth Floor Printer" -Name printer.contoso.com

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the name and description for an existing DHCPv4 reservation for IP address 10.10.10.5.
